presentation.title: The API Economy
presentation.toc: APIs are a big trend, and that's mostly because they are an indicator for big changes in the business landscape: Businesses get both more connected and more loosely coupled at the same time: Connected because businesses increasingly focus on profitable parts of the value chain, attempting to commoditize the rest. Loosely coupled because business models need to be developed and tweaked and changed at an increasing pace, and thus more easily and at lower cost. This presentation looks at the resulting challenges and trends of APIs and API strategies, with a specific focus of the current Fintech landscape.

Companies need to act/react/change quicker
Business contexts change often and possibly radically
Companies need to adapt faster to these changes
Value chains become more complex and reconfigure more often
Businesses are built on platforms
External resources are used strategically
Product resources are built and provided strategically
Internal/external product distinction is policy-only
Resource ecosystems are the enabler of fast changes
PSD2 forces banks to provide banking APIs
Functional requirements are specified by the PSD2 directive
Technical specification is up to the financial institutions
Business models will change but many open questions
Will banks compete on API design or functionality?
Are there non-regulated angles for differentiation?
How will the ecosystem of API-based services look like?
Nobody knows how things will change, everybody knows that things will change
The only visibility into a service is its API
APIs should avoid letting their implementation shine through
The two main goals of an API are interaction and encapsulation
Interaction should be as simple/easy as possible through the API
Encapsulation ensures that the implementation is invisible
Help developers to navigate the evolving landscape of interlinked APIs
The Castle is not going anywhere anytime soon
Managing interactions with one or more castles is a standard problem
Merchants should focus on their business instead of the foundation
There is more than one castle and they have different APIs
Markets/Merchants are much more dynamic than Castles
Developing and offering a product is easier on a market
APIs are connective tissue and protective insulation layers
Merchants should focus on optimizing their differential in the value chain
Set yourself up to build quickly (possibly loosely coupled)
Set yourself up to adapt quickly (shield yourself from change)
Set yourself up to re-productize quickly
